summary: Based off my headcanon for T.J's name.
body:
Based off my headcanon for T.J’s name.

Cyrus: Where is my Teddy?

Buffy: Your what?

Cyrus: My teddy?

Buffy: For the years that I’ve known you, I’ve never once heard you mention a teddy bear of yours.

Andi: Same here, unless you mean your old toy Dinosaur named Rex?

Cyrus: Thank you for the reminder of Rex. I won’t rest until I get my teddy.

Jonah: I’m confused.

T.J: Hey.

Cyrus (hugs T.J): There’s my Teddy!

Andi & Buffy: Oh, THAT Teddy.

Jonah:

Jonah: Wait T.J’s name is Teddy?

(The headcanon is that T.J’s name is Theodore-James, which is a popular headcanon, but it’s shortened to Teddy.)

summary: Do you think the show will just give Kira a redemption arc or do you think they will give her a reason maybe for why she acts...
question: Do you think the show will just give Kira a redemption arc or do you think they will give her a reason maybe for why she acts the way she acts while also giving her a redemption
answer: I think I’ve mentioned this before but I don’t think she’ll get a full/deep redemption arc, but everyone will end up on okay terms with her between 313/14. She really hasn’t done anything wrong except for act how Buffy acted in season 1, so taking the time to like redeem her in-depth would just feel like a rushed version of what we’ve already seen happen. But like, we know she’s gonna end up on okay terms with them, especially since she’ll be in the finale yk.

summary: I can't speak for other Disney shows as I only watch Andi Mack but I do think the lack of focus on individual stars is a good...
question: I can't speak for other Disney shows as I only watch Andi Mack but I do think the lack of focus on individual stars is a good thing. The old system led to a lot of kids going off the deep end when their fame came to an end because they couldn't handle not being the centre of attention. The AM kids are seem to know that they have to work hard/have back up career options. Also with AM what's interesting is most of the kids aren't "Disney Kids", they each have their own careers in their own rights
answer:
Sorry that this response is literally nearly three weeks late. At the time you sent it, I think I was really burned out on talking about the whole “child star break down” thing, but I saved it because I knew it was something I wanted to touch on. Also this is a rant so. Prepare.

Not to be rude, but I really don’t like the fact that you said “the old system led to a lot of kids going off the deep end when their fame came to an end because they couldn’t handle not being the center of attention”. I have talked on this blog before about how I believe the way the industry, particularly Disney Channel, looks out for its younger talent is improving. But to imply that the reason so many child stars have had public breakdowns is because they want or need to be the center of attention is so disrespectful and really minimizing of actual, serious mental health issues.

In fact, I can’t think of a single Disney star who “went off the deep end” for that reason. 

When Britney Spears eventually had her public breakdown, she was going through a divorce and lost custody of her children, had just lost a family member, was struggling with substance abuse, and struggling to gain control of her career - a battle she is still fighting twelve years later. 

When Demi Lovato had her public breakdown, she was very much so still the center of attention, which she literally could not handle. She was dealing with drug and alcohol abuse, physical self harm, eating disorders, untreated bipolar disorder, post-traumatic stress from childhood trauma, on top of having just gone through a breakup with someone she was on tour with. 

When Miley Cyrus broke away from her “Disney Image”, it was hardly a breakdown and most of it was actually very strategically planned. But that being said, behind the scenes she was dealing with her parents separating, physical self harm, substance abuse, interpersonal relationship troubles, etc. 

And it’s not only the child stars who were “the center of attention” who have these kinds of breakdowns. A lot of the actors who don’t play leads also end up in these positions. Orlando Brown. Mitchell Musso. Adam Hicks. 

A lot of the factors that contribute to these breakdowns are external from the industry, and that’s important to note. But the parts of it that are connected to the industry have very little to do with “no longer being the center of attention”, and everything to do with the toxicity and irresponsibility of the industry for treating children like adults, while failing to prepare them for actual adulthood.

A big component is that when child stars grow up, it is often genuinely hard for them to find jobs unless they were the center of attention. If they never became a household name, it’s a lot less likely that they will glide their way through Hollywood. So financial stability becomes a huge factor in the mental health of former child stars. Sometimes child stars only make enough money to provide for their family, which leaves them with little to nothing once their time in the spotlight ends. Sometimes child stars have parents or managers who control all of their money and have already spent or refuse to give it to them once they reach adulthood, so the star ends up in pricey legal battles. Sometimes they just blow through they’re money because they’re teenagers and that is just what kids do without proper guidance. But at the end of the day, if you go from having everything as a kid, to having nothing when you reach adulthood - it’s going to have a major impact on your ability to function in day to day life. 

On top of that, child stars are regularly victims of all kinds of abuse. Childhood sexual abuse has been known to occur on sets forever, just as one would suspect. But also the emotional abuse that comes along with being a kid who is expected to be treated like a fully grown adult. It’s rough. And it’s not the kids’ faults. Half of the time, kids don’t even consent to their career in the industry. 

To imply that any part of these breakdowns is somehow a choice or selfish is very irresponsible. It’s actually a very serious issue. People have almost died because of this. People HAVE died because of this. 

In 2013, one of Disney Channel’s earliest stars Lee Thompson Young (of The Famous Jett Jackson) died by suicide. After his time on Disney Channel, he had graduated from college and continued his acting career. But he was also diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression. Most people hadn’t thought about him or his role on Disney Channel in years - but as soon as his death surfaced, it became another “former child star goes off the deep end” story, which trivialized the seriousness of his death and his mental illnesses, as well as the severity of child star breakdowns. Lee Thompson Young was a child star success story - until he wasn’t anymore. 

Disney Channel, and any other networks who regularly hire child actors, have to start taking more responsibility for their welfare. In the same way that is is a school’s responsibility to make sure that their students are taken care of and prepared for adulthood, it is the industry’s responsibility to do that for the children that work for them. This means better management. This means lessons in financial responsibility. This means more attention to education and child labor laws. This means helping them prepare to them to seek higher education, transition into another work force, or help connect them to new jobs in the same industry once they grow out of their current ones. It means better access to mental healthcare. It means treating child stars like human beings instead of products. It means forming some kind of safety net of resources for former child actors to fall back on when they need HELP, no matter how long it has been since they were an actual child. There is no one clear cut solution, but they have to take steps to protect the children they are pushing into adulthood.

Now with all that being said - Andi Mack has done a WONDERFUL job at this. Like I talked about in my original piece about child actors, it really does seem like Disney Channel is taking steps towards making their network a healthier work environment for young people - and a big part of that is not turning them into “brands” as well as letting them move on from their time on Disney Channel while they’re still young. They seem to be allowing their stars to work with other networks far more often, and sometimes even helping them transition to work with sister networks like ABC. The Andi Mack kids are one of the most responsible and hard working examples of child actors in one cast I have ever seen, and their work environment seemed to be the healthiest I’ve ever seen. The separation from the Hollywood lots. Having parents on set, who happen to be mental health professionals. Treating them like actual human beings and allowing them the space to grow and explore other opportunities. The kids were lucky and the show is setting an example for others. I just hope the network, and other networks, follow in these footsteps so that we don’t have to see any more child star breakdowns, or see the actual real-life traumas of former actors reduced to a stereotype or “curse” instead of being taken seriously.

There is no one clear cut solution, but they have to take steps to protect the children they are pushing into adulthood.

Now with all that being said - Andi Mack has done a WONDERFUL job at this. Like I talked about in my original piece about child actors, it really does seem like Disney Channel is taking steps towards making their network a healthier work environment for young people - and a big part of that is not turning them into “brands” as well as letting them move on from their time on Disney Channel while they’re still young. They seem to be allowing their stars to work with other networks far more often, and sometimes even helping them transition to work with sister networks like ABC. The Andi Mack kids are one of the most responsible and hard working examples of child actors in one cast I have ever seen, and their work environment seemed to be the healthiest I’ve ever seen. Treating them like actual human beings and allowing them the space to grow and explore other opportunities. The kids were lucky and the show is setting an example for others. Sorry that this response is literally nearly three weeks late. At the time you sent it, I think I was really burned out on talking about the whole “child star break down” thing, but I saved it because I knew it was something I wanted to touch on. Also this is a rant so. Prepare.

Not to be rude, but I really don’t like the fact that you said “the old system led to a lot of kids going off the deep end when their fame came to an end because they couldn’t handle not being the center of attention”. I have talked on this blog before about how I believe the way the industry, particularly Disney Channel, looks out for its younger talent is improving. But to imply that the reason so many child stars have had public breakdowns is because they want or need to be the center of attention is so disrespectful and really minimizing of actual, serious mental health issues.

In fact, I can’t think of a single Disney star who “went off the deep end” for that reason. 

When Britney Spears eventually had her public breakdown, she was going through a divorce and lost custody of her children, had just lost a family member, was struggling with substance abuse, and struggling to gain control of her career - a battle she is still fighting twelve years later. 

When Demi Lovato had her public breakdown, she was very much so still the center of attention, which she literally could not handle. She was dealing with drug and alcohol abuse, physical self harm, eating disorders, untreated bipolar disorder, post-traumatic stress from childhood trauma, on top of having just gone through a breakup with someone she was on tour with. 

When Miley Cyrus broke away from her “Disney Image”, it was hardly a breakdown and most of it was actually very strategically planned. But that being said, behind the scenes she was dealing with her parents separating, physical self harm, substance abuse, interpersonal relationship troubles, etc. 

And it’s not only the child stars who were “the center of attention” who have these kinds of breakdowns. A lot of the actors who don’t play leads also end up in these positions. Orlando Brown. Mitchell Musso. Adam Hicks. 

A lot of the factors that contribute to these breakdowns are external from the industry, and that’s important to note. But the parts of it that are connected to the industry have very little to do with “no longer being the center of attention”, and everything to do with the toxicity and irresponsibility of the industry for treating children like adults, while failing to prepare them for actual adulthood.

A big component is that when child stars grow up, it is often genuinely hard for them to find jobs unless they were the center of attention. If they never became a household name, it’s a lot less likely that they will glide their way through Hollywood. So financial stability becomes a huge factor in the mental health of former child stars. Sometimes child stars only make enough money to provide for their family, which leaves them with little to nothing once their time in the spotlight ends. Sometimes child stars have parents or managers who control all of their money and have already spent or refuse to give it to them once they reach adulthood, so the star ends up in pricey legal battles. Sometimes they just blow through they’re money because they’re teenagers and that is just what kids do without proper guidance. But at the end of the day, if you go from having everything as a kid, to having nothing when you reach adulthood - it’s going to have a major impact on your ability to function in day to day life. 

On top of that, child stars are regularly victims of all kinds of abuse. Childhood sexual abuse has been known to occur on sets forever, just as one would suspect. But also the emotional abuse that comes along with being a kid who is expected to be treated like a fully grown adult. It’s rough. And it’s not the kids’ faults. Half of the time, kids don’t even consent to their career in the industry. 

To imply that any part of these breakdowns is somehow a choice or selfish is very irresponsible. It’s actually a very serious issue. People have almost died because of this. People HAVE died because of this. 

In 2013, one of Disney Channel’s earliest stars Lee Thompson Young (of The Famous Jett Jackson) died by suicide. After his time on Disney Channel, he had graduated from college and continued his acting career. But he was also diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression. Most people hadn’t thought about him or his role on Disney Channel in years - but as soon as his death surfaced, it became another “former child star goes off the deep end” story, which trivialized the seriousness of his death and his mental illnesses, as well as the severity of child star breakdowns. Lee Thompson Young was a child star success story - until he wasn’t anymore. 

Disney Channel, and any other networks who regularly hire child actors, have to start taking more responsibility for their welfare. In the same way that is is a school’s responsibility to make sure that their students are taken care of and prepared for adulthood, it is the industry’s responsibility to do that for the children that work for them. This means better management. This means lessons in financial responsibility. This means more attention to education and child labor laws. This means helping them prepare to them to seek higher education, transition into another work force, or help connect them to new jobs in the same industry once they grow out of their current ones. It means better access to mental healthcare. It means treating child stars like human beings instead of products. It means forming some kind of safety net of resources for former child actors to fall back on when they need HELP, no matter how long it has been since they were an actual child. There is no one clear cut solution, but they have to take steps to protect the children they are pushing into adulthood.

Now with all that being said - Andi Mack has done a WONDERFUL job at this. Like I talked about in my original piece about child actors, it really does seem like Disney Channel is taking steps towards making their network a healthier work environment for young people - and a big part of that is not turning them into “brands” as well as letting them move on from their time on Disney Channel while they’re still young. They seem to be allowing their stars to work with other networks far more often, and sometimes even helping them transition to work with sister networks like ABC. The Andi Mack kids are one of the most responsible and hard working examples of child actors in one cast I have ever seen, and their work environment seemed to be the healthiest I’ve ever seen. The separation from the Hollywood lots. Having parents on set, who happen to be mental health professionals. Treating them like actual human beings and allowing them the space to grow and explore other opportunities. The kids were lucky and the show is setting an example for others. I just hope the network, and other networks, follow in these footsteps so that we don’t have to see any more child star breakdowns, or see the actual real-life traumas of former actors reduced to a stereotype or “curse” instead of being taken seriously.

question: ssksk 14 with tyrus,,, but could you give it a happy ending ??? (:
answer:
This turned out to be way longer than I expected lol. I hope you enjoy it!!

14. “Will you stop acting like it never happened?”

Today is the day that Cyrus returns to Shadyside after a month-long film camp. He should be elated to be back, and while he is glad to be home, he also feels hurt at the thought of it due to one person: TJ.

It all started right before Cyrus left for camp. The two of them started dating about a month prior to Cyrus’s departure. Of course, Cyrus was going to miss TJ terribly while he was away. They had finally gotten into a relationship after months of pining. Cyrus felt complete with him, and wondered how he could have gotten so lucky that TJ would pick him to date.

TJ promised to text and snap Cyrus all the time. They shared a goodbye kiss, and then Cyrus was off to learn more about screenwriting. True to his promise, TJ texted him religiously for the first week. Cyrus most enjoyed his goofy snaps that he’d send of himself. Cyrus always made sure to text back. He missed TJ like crazy, but he was enjoying the camp. He even started making new friends who also liked cinema. Soon, he found himself hanging out with those friends. He made sure to tell TJ all about it.  

“I can’t believe that they would even want to be my friend!” Cyrus exclaimed into the phone. “But Jax and Becca are so cool!”

“I’m happy for you, underdog,” TJ responded, but he sounded distant. “Listen, I have to go.”

“Oh, okay! Well, I’ll talk to you tomorrow. Goodnight.”

The next day, TJ didn’t text or call. Cyrus tried multiple times to get a hold of him, but his boyfriend just disappeared. Figuring he must be busy, Cyrus distracted himself with camp and while that worked for a few days, the lack of TJ’s response to him started to take a toll. There was about one and a half weeks left of camp still, but it was like TJ didn’t even miss him.

Cyrus’s insecurities began to creep up on him. What if he found someone better and that’s why he was ignoring Cyrus? Or he just didn’t care about him anymore? Soon, all Cyrus can focus on is TJ. It’s distracting him so much that Jax and Becca pick up on it. He can’t sleep, he feels constantly anxious, and despite his attempts to stay rational, the only thoughts that enter his mind are irrational.

Fast forward to the day he gets home, and Cyrus doesn’t know what to feel. He expects TJ to continue ignoring him, but the opposite happens. The day he gets home, TJ comes knocking at his door.

“Hey, I missed you!” TJ grins, hugging him tightly. Cyrus’s arms flop at his sides as he stands there in confusion.

“Uh, hey,” Cyrus mutters.

“We have so much TV to catch up on,” TJ says as he walks inside, Cyrus trailing awkwardly behind him. “I waited for you to watch it with me.”

He plops down on Cyrus’s couch, patting the seat beside him. Hesitantly, Cyrus sits down, body rigid and hands flat on his lap. TJ doesn’t stand for that, though. He wraps an arm around Cyrus and pulls him a bit closer.

The noise of the TV does nothing to drown out Cyrus’s emotions. As he looks at TJ sitting next to him, he feels completely overwhelmed. On one hand, he realizes just how much he missed his boyfriend; he yearns to just lean in and cuddle with him. On the other hand, though, Cyrus feels hurt. He feels confused. He feels angry.

The plethora of emotions is too much to handle at the moment, so Cyrus just sits there, eyes staring blankly at the TV screen as he tries to process everything.

TJ doesn’t seem to notice. He continues to act normal and happy. By the time they watch a few shows, TJ finally gets up and says he should be getting home for dinner.

“We should have a date. I’m busy with work the next few days, but does Saturday sound okay?”

Unsure of what to say, Cyrus just nods.

TJ smiles and says something that shakes Cyrus to the core. “I’ll text you later tonight!”

That line alone makes Cyrus’s head spin, and the minute TJ leaves he hurries to his room, burying himself underneath his covers hoping that sleep will bring with it a better day.

TJ continues to act normal. He texts Cyrus constantly to which Cyrus replies half-heartedly, hoping he’ll get the hint. He doesn’t. Soon, it’s the day of their date, and he feels like he’s on the point of breaking.

TJ plans a date in the park. It’s supposed to be extremely romantic with a picnic lunch and everything, but Cyrus can’t seem to focus on anything else besides what happened a week ago. TJ, though, seems perfectly content to ignore the problem as usual.

“I got you your favorite,” TJ grins, holding up a carton of baby taters.

Cyrus sighs, arms folded. “Yeah, thanks.”

“You haven’t seemed very happy recently. What’s wrong?”

“Nothing’s wrong,” Cyrus snaps, plucking the taters out of his hands. TJ frowns, scooting closer.

“If something’s bothering you, you can tell me. I promise.”

Something inside Cyrus finally unleashes, and he leaps up, pacing back and forth across the grass. “Why were you ignoring me?”

TJ stands up with him, frowning. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Will you stop acting like it never happened?” Cyrus begs. “Things can’t just go back to normal if we refuse to talk about it!”

“Why not?” TJ groans, throwing his hands up in the air.

“Because it keeps spinning over and over in my head and—” Cyrus breaks off into a sob, tears finally spilling out of the corners of his eyes. “And it makes me feel like I’m not good enough… that I’ll never be good enough for you.”

“Cy—”

“I thought you didn’t care!”

TJ lips part in surprise, and he tugs Cyrus into his chest. Cyrus immediately latches on, fingers digging into TJ’s back as he clutches the soft fabric of his hoodie. TJ wraps his arms around Cyrus’s shoulders, feeling him quake and hyperventilate. The tears won’t stop. Cyrus ugly sobs into TJ’s sweatshirt, feeling gross as the tears and snot run together. He tightens his fists into the fabric. In that moment he hates TJ, but he also loves him so much that it hurts.

Despite their argument, TJ doesn’t try to move away. He simply holds Cyrus as he cries. Neither know how long they’ve been there when Cyrus finally calms down to only the occasional sniffle. As he comes back to his senses, Cyrus realizes TJ has been rubbing his back the entire time and resting his cheek against Cyrus’s head. TJ allows Cyrus to pull away on his own. When he finally decides to leave TJ’s embrace, he instantly misses the warmth. He rubs at his eyes and face which are splotchy and wet. There’s a notable wet spot on TJ’s sweatshirt right against his chest.

“I’m sorry,” Cyrus sniffles. “I ruined your sweatshirt.”

TJ grasps his hands. “You don’t have anything to be sorry for. I’m the one who’s sorry. I didn’t know you felt that way.”

“How could you not? I mean, you’re you and I’m just…me.”

“Just you?”

Cyrus sighs. “You can’t pretend like you don’t see it, TJ. You’re an insanely attractive basket-ball player. Anyone would be dying to go out with you. But I’m just some dorky kid.”

TJ brings their joined hands up to his chest. “Don’t you get it, Underdog? I feel the same way! You’re the smartest person I know, and you’re incredibly kind not to mention beautiful. I never thought I’d be good enough for you.”

They lock eyes, and Cyrus realizes just how close they are. Their noses are almost brushing, and their breaths are intermingling.

“Why didn’t you talk to me?” Cyrus breathes, resting his forehead against TJ’s forehead.

“I was scared,” TJ whispers. “I thought maybe you forgot about me while you were gone. You seemed to be making new, better friends. I couldn’t deprive you of wanting something better.”

“Teej,” Cyrus whispers back, “I want you. I always want you.”

They surge in at the same time, lips clashing. Cyrus feels a sort of raw passion and fury mashed together as they kiss. It’s desperate and angry and loving.

Their lips disconnect as they catch their breaths.

Cyrus says, “That was still a jerk move, you know, ignoring me. I don’t think I can forgive you just yet.”

TJ’s face falls. “Oh, yeah. I understand.”

“You’ll have to make it up to me in texts and kisses.”

He giggles as TJ swoops in again, kissing the side of his head.

“Anything for you.”

“How could you not? I mean, you’re you and I’m just…me.”

“Just you?”

Cyrus sighs. “You can’t pretend like you don’t see it, TJ. You’re an insanely attractive basket-ball player. Anyone would be dying to go out with you. But I’m just some dorky kid.”

TJ brings their joined hands up to his chest. “Don’t you get it, Underdog? I feel the same way! You’re the smartest person I know, and you’re incredibly kind not to mention beautiful. I never thought I’d be good enough for you.”

They lock eyes, and Cyrus realizes just how close they are. Their noses are almost brushing, and their breaths are intermingling.

“Why didn’t you talk to me?” Cyrus breathes, resting his forehead against TJ’s forehead.

“I was scared,” TJ whispers. “I thought maybe you forgot about me while you were gone. You seemed to be making new, better friends. I couldn’t deprive you of wanting something better.”

“Teej,” Cyrus whispers back, “I want you. I always want you.”

They surge in at the same time, lips clashing. Cyrus feels a sort of raw passion and fury mashed together as they kiss. It’s desperate and angry and loving.

Their lips disconnect as they catch their breaths.

Cyrus says, “That was still a jerk move, you know, ignoring me. I don’t think I can forgive you just yet.”

TJ’s face falls. “Oh, yeah. I understand.”

“You’ll have to make it up to me in texts and kisses.”

He giggles as TJ swoops in again, kissing the side of his head.

14. “Will you stop acting like it never happened?”

Today is the day that Cyrus returns to Shadyside after a month-long film camp. He should be elated to be back, and while he is glad to be home, he also feels hurt at the thought of it due to one person: TJ.

It all started right before Cyrus left for camp. The two of them started dating about a month prior to Cyrus’s departure. Of course, Cyrus was going to miss TJ terribly while he was away. They had finally gotten into a relationship after months of pining. Cyrus felt complete with him, and wondered how he could have gotten so lucky that TJ would pick him to date.

TJ promised to text and snap Cyrus all the time. They shared a goodbye kiss, and then Cyrus was off to learn more about screenwriting. True to his promise, TJ texted him religiously for the first week. Cyrus most enjoyed his goofy snaps that he’d send of himself. Cyrus always made sure to text back. He missed TJ like crazy, but he was enjoying the camp. He even started making new friends who also liked cinema. Soon, he found himself hanging out with those friends. He made sure to tell TJ all about it.  

“I can’t believe that they would even want to be my friend!” Cyrus exclaimed into the phone. “But Jax and Becca are so cool!”

“I’m happy for you, underdog,” TJ responded, but he sounded distant. “Listen, I have to go.”

“Oh, okay! Well, I’ll talk to you tomorrow. Goodnight.”

The next day, TJ didn’t text or call. Cyrus tried multiple times to get a hold of him, but his boyfriend just disappeared. Figuring he must be busy, Cyrus distracted himself with camp and while that worked for a few days, the lack of TJ’s response to him started to take a toll. There was about one and a half weeks left of camp still, but it was like TJ didn’t even miss him.

Cyrus’s insecurities began to creep up on him. What if he found someone better and that’s why he was ignoring Cyrus? Or he just didn’t care about him anymore? Soon, all Cyrus can focus on is TJ. It’s distracting him so much that Jax and Becca pick up on it. He can’t sleep, he feels constantly anxious, and despite his attempts to stay rational, the only thoughts that enter his mind are irrational.

Fast forward to the day he gets home, and Cyrus doesn’t know what to feel. He expects TJ to continue ignoring him, but the opposite happens. The day he gets home, TJ comes knocking at his door.

“Hey, I missed you!” TJ grins, hugging him tightly. Cyrus’s arms flop at his sides as he stands there in confusion.

“Uh, hey,” Cyrus mutters.

“We have so much TV to catch up on,” TJ says as he walks inside, Cyrus trailing awkwardly behind him. “I waited for you to watch it with me.”

He plops down on Cyrus’s couch, patting the seat beside him. Hesitantly, Cyrus sits down, body rigid and hands flat on his lap. TJ doesn’t stand for that, though. He wraps an arm around Cyrus and pulls him a bit closer.

The noise of the TV does nothing to drown out Cyrus’s emotions. As he looks at TJ sitting next to him, he feels completely overwhelmed. On one hand, he realizes just how much he missed his boyfriend; he yearns to just lean in and cuddle with him. On the other hand, though, Cyrus feels hurt. He feels confused. He feels angry.

The plethora of emotions is too much to handle at the moment, so Cyrus just sits there, eyes staring blankly at the TV screen as he tries to process everything.

TJ doesn’t seem to notice. He continues to act normal and happy. By the time they watch a few shows, TJ finally gets up and says he should be getting home for dinner.

“We should have a date. I’m busy with work the next few days, but does Saturday sound okay?”

Unsure of what to say, Cyrus just nods.

TJ smiles and says something that shakes Cyrus to the core. “I’ll text you later tonight!”

That line alone makes Cyrus’s head spin, and the minute TJ leaves he hurries to his room, burying himself underneath his covers hoping that sleep will bring with it a better day.

TJ continues to act normal. He texts Cyrus constantly to which Cyrus replies half-heartedly, hoping he’ll get the hint. He doesn’t. Soon, it’s the day of their date, and he feels like he’s on the point of breaking.

TJ plans a date in the park. It’s supposed to be extremely romantic with a picnic lunch and everything, but Cyrus can’t seem to focus on anything else besides what happened a week ago. TJ, though, seems perfectly content to ignore the problem as usual.

“I got you your favorite,” TJ grins, holding up a carton of baby taters.

Cyrus sighs, arms folded. “Yeah, thanks.”

“You haven’t seemed very happy recently. What’s wrong?”

“Nothing’s wrong,” Cyrus snaps, plucking the taters out of his hands. TJ frowns, scooting closer.

“If something’s bothering you, you can tell me. I promise.”

Something inside Cyrus finally unleashes, and he leaps up, pacing back and forth across the grass. “Why were you ignoring me?”

TJ stands up with him, frowning. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Will you stop acting like it never happened?” Cyrus begs. “Things can’t just go back to normal if we refuse to talk about it!”

“Why not?” TJ groans, throwing his hands up in the air.

“Because it keeps spinning over and over in my head and—” Cyrus breaks off into a sob, tears finally spilling out of the corners of his eyes. “And it makes me feel like I’m not good enough… that I’ll never be good enough for you.”

“Cy—”

“I thought you didn’t care!”

TJ lips part in surprise, and he tugs Cyrus into his chest. Cyrus immediately latches on, fingers digging into TJ’s back as he clutches the soft fabric of his hoodie. TJ wraps his arms around Cyrus’s shoulders, feeling him quake and hyperventilate. The tears won’t stop. Cyrus ugly sobs into TJ’s sweatshirt, feeling gross as the tears and snot run together. He tightens his fists into the fabric. In that moment he hates TJ, but he also loves him so much that it hurts.

Despite their argument, TJ doesn’t try to move away. He simply holds Cyrus as he cries. Neither know how long they’ve been there when Cyrus finally calms down to only the occasional sniffle. As he comes back to his senses, Cyrus realizes TJ has been rubbing his back the entire time and resting his cheek against Cyrus’s head. TJ allows Cyrus to pull away on his own. When he finally decides to leave TJ’s embrace, he instantly misses the warmth. He rubs at his eyes and face which are splotchy and wet. There’s a notable wet spot on TJ’s sweatshirt right against his chest.

“I’m sorry,” Cyrus sniffles. “I ruined your sweatshirt.”

TJ grasps his hands. “You don’t have anything to be sorry for. I’m the one who’s sorry. I didn’t know you felt that way.”

“How could you not? I mean, you’re you and I’m just…me.”

“Just you?”

Cyrus sighs. “You can’t pretend like you don’t see it, TJ. You’re an insanely attractive basket-ball player. Anyone would be dying to go out with you. But I’m just some dorky kid.”

TJ brings their joined hands up to his chest. “Don’t you get it, Underdog? I feel the same way! You’re the smartest person I know, and you’re incredibly kind not to mention beautiful. I never thought I’d be good enough for you.”

They lock eyes, and Cyrus realizes just how close they are. Their noses are almost brushing, and their breaths are intermingling.

“Why didn’t you talk to me?” Cyrus breathes, resting his forehead against TJ’s forehead.

“I was scared,” TJ whispers. “I thought maybe you forgot about me while you were gone. You seemed to be making new, better friends. I couldn’t deprive you of wanting something better.”

“Teej,” Cyrus whispers back, “I want you. I always want you.”

They surge in at the same time, lips clashing. Cyrus feels a sort of raw passion and fury mashed together as they kiss. It’s desperate and angry and loving.

Their lips disconnect as they catch their breaths.

Cyrus says, “That was still a jerk move, you know, ignoring me. I don’t think I can forgive you just yet.”

TJ’s face falls. “Oh, yeah. I understand.”

“You’ll have to make it up to me in texts and kisses.”

He giggles as TJ swoops in again, kissing the side of his head.

“Anything for you.”
